G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson (“Plaintiff” or “Mother”), and pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody and parenting time order entered on **May 15, 2019** by this Court concerning the minor child, **Ethan Thompson**, born in 2017.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson (“Plaintiff” or “Mother”), and pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody and parenting time order entered on **May 15, 2019** by this Court concerning the minor child, **Ethan Thompson**, born in 2017.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The material changes described above directly affect the child’s welfare and warrant judicial modification of the prior custody order in accordance with **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: Hunter v. Rose is a custody case applying a best-interests analysis between two legal parents, but it does not address the standard for *modification* of a prior custody order based on material and substantial changes in circumstances. The opinion contains no discussion of the modification framework or the requirement that post-judgment changes directly affect the child’s welfare so as to warrant altering an existing custody judgment. That modification principle comes from cases like Custody of Kali and Yannas, not from Hunter.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The material changes described above directly affect the child’s welfare and warrant judicial modification of the prior custody order in accordance with **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for *modification* of an existing custody judgment based on material changes affecting the child’s welfare. Custody of Kali explicitly declines to apply or discuss the G.L. c. 209C, § 20 "substantial change in circumstances" modification standard and instead treats the case as an initial custody determination under § 10(a) using a best-interests analysis. Because the court does not hold that material changes warrant modification of a prior order, Kali does not provide authority for that specific modification proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The material changes described above directly affect the child’s welfare and warrant judicial modification of the prior custody order in accordance with **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification case based on material changes in circumstances. The opinion articulates the ‘real advantage’ and best‑interests analysis for allowing a custodial parent to remove children from the Commonwealth, but it does not address when post‑divorce changes warrant judicial modification of an existing custody order. Citing Yannas as authority that material changes directly affecting a child’s welfare justify modifying a prior custody order therefore overreads its holding and context.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30… provides that… [a child] shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change….”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting order when there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and modification is necessary to serve the **best interests of the child**, per **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, and **Murray v. Super**, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses modification actions (removal and child support) and cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 only in connection with child support, not custody or parenting-time modification standards. The court never articulates the rule that a Probate and Family Court may modify custody/parenting orders upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and necessity for the child’s best interests; instead, the custody-related analysis is framed under the Yannas ‘real advantage’/best interests removal standard and G.L. c. 208, § 30. Thus, Murray v. Super does not provide direct authority for the claimed proposition about custody modification under § 28.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 2011, c. 93, § 37, provides that a child support order shall be modified ‘if there is an inconsistency between the amount of the existing order and the amount that would result from application of the child support guidelines.’ Although the father alleged that there had been a material change of circumstances, the judge here was correct to apply those guidelines to the parties’ updated financial circumstances.”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody determinations in the Commonwealth, see **Custody of a Minor**, 389 Mass. 755 (1983); **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion does not state that a free‑floating “best interests of the child” test governs all custody determinations in Massachusetts. Instead, it emphasizes that when the State seeks to remove custody from a natural parent (whether under care and protection, guardianship, or adoption statutes), the controlling standard is parental unfitness proven by clear and convincing evidence, with best interests linked to—but not replacing—the fitness inquiry. The case thus cabins the best‑interests concept within an unfitness framework rather than announcing it as the universal governing standard for all custody determinations.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “[T]he unfitness standard must be applied whenever the State seeks to terminate parents’ rights to the custody of their minor children, whether the State proceeds under the care and protection statute (G. L. c. 119, §§ 23-29), the guardianship statute (G. L. c. 201, § 5), or the adoption statute (G. L. c. 210, § 3). … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’ In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody determinations in the Commonwealth, see **Custody of a Minor**, 389 Mass. 755 (1983); **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the best-interests standard in the context of modification of custody and removal, but it does not announce any broad rule that the best interests of the child standard governs all custody determinations in Massachusetts. The case cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 for the requirement that a modification be "necessary in the best interests of the children," and discusses Yannas/Hale removal factors, but nowhere states or suggests a universal proposition covering all types of custody determinations in the Commonwealth. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the sweeping proposition quoted.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 ("the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children").

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Significant changes in a parent’s living situation and the child’s age, schooling, or developmental stage have repeatedly been held sufficient to justify modification.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The case concerns a removal request and modification of a divorce judgment based on the mother’s remarriage, not on generalized changes in living situation or the children’s age, schooling, or developmental stage. The opinion discusses what constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances” and holds that remarriage is such a change, but it does not state or survey a rule that significant changes in a parent’s living circumstances together with the child’s age/schooling/development have repeatedly been held sufficient to justify modification. The proposition therefore overstates and mischaracterizes what this case stands for.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “In the present case, the judge may also have been influenced in his view of the mother’s remarriage and accompanying desire to move by his opinion that no changed circumstances were present, and thus no ground existed for modifying the divorce judgment. … Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification. … In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: Significant changes in a parent’s living situation and the child’s age, schooling, or developmental stage have repeatedly been held sufficient to justify modification.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with initial divorce, property division, support, fees, and custody, and briefly corrects the procedural vehicle for changing custody (requiring a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28). It does not analyze what constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances to justify modification, nor does it discuss changes in a parent’s living situation or the child’s age, schooling, or developmental stage as grounds for modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Significant changes in a parent’s living situation and the child’s age, schooling, or developmental stage have repeatedly been held sufficient to justify modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with the standards for making an initial custody award and the need to base custody determinations on the child’s welfare and a weighing of relevant factors. It does not address post-judgment modification standards, nor does it discuss significant changes in a parent’s living situation or the child’s age, schooling, or developmental stage as grounds for modification. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification-related proposition claimed.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of her father at his home and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

J.F. v. J.F., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (200.raw_text: J.F. v. J.F., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (2008)
J.F. v. J.F., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (200.proposition: Significant changes in a parent’s living situation and the child’s age, schooling, or developmental stage have repeatedly been held sufficient to justify modification.
J.F. v. J.F., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (200.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether summary judgment was proper in a custody-modification action where the father alleged emotional neglect and the child’s preference to live with him. The court discusses what can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances, focusing on emotional neglect and the child’s increasing, well‑reasoned preference, not on changes in a parent’s living situation or the child’s age, schooling, or developmental stage as independent bases. It does not articulate or affirm any general rule that significant changes in living arrangements or in the child’s age/schooling/developmental stage, by themselves or repeatedly in other cases, are sufficient to justify modification.
J.F. v. J.F., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (200.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a judge of the Probate and Family Court may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … [T]here was evidence in the present case in (at least) the form of Tom’s complaints … [and] concerns about Tom being ‘more than just unhappy’ and ‘at risk to becoming clinically depressed’ … which, when viewed in the light most favorable to the father, could support a finding of a material change in circumstances.”}

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court retains broad equitable powers to adjust parenting schedules where necessary to promote the stability and welfare of the child, **G.L. c. 215, § 6**; **Yannas**, 395 Mass. at 710.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Public policy strongly favors maintaining continuing and meaningful relationships between a child and both parents consistent with the child’s best interests, **G.L. c. 208, § 31**; **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Public policy strongly favors maintaining continuing and meaningful relationships between a child and both parents consistent with the child’s best interests, **G.L. c. 208, § 31**; **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly acknowledges the legal value of a child’s relationship with both parents, citing Felton and endorsing the idea that the law sees value in “frequent and continuing contact” with both parents. Although the court ultimately upholds reduced visitation based on the best interests of the children, its reasoning explicitly affirms the general policy favoring the child’s ongoing relationships with both parents, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 31, and balances that policy against best-interest considerations.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 234, quoting from In re Marriage of Murga, 103 Cal. App. 3d 498, 503 (1980) … Children are entitled to the love, companionship and concern of both parents…”
